Award.AwardTitle: Structure and Function of Holliday Junctions complexed With Proteins Probed by Fluorescence and UV Raman Spectroscopic Methods

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies a central intermediate in the important cellular processes of DNA recombination and repair, which rely on the exchange of homologous DNA strands through a four-stranded structure or Holliday junction. Both DNA repair and recombination are vital functions of the cell, which are needed for cell proliferation and maintaining a stable and active genome. Errors in these processes can lead to the growth of tumors and a reduced life span. Protein- and ion-binding leads to a change in junction structure. This study specifically examines how proteins that are known to be involved in repair and recombination and are known to bind to junctions alter these structures. In particular, the ability of these proteins to either facilitate or suppress the exchanging of strands is addressed by studying the structures of the protein-DNA complexes. Two different methods are used to study the interactions: fluorescence spectroscopy and a laser technique, UV resonance Raman spectroscopy. Using the fluorescence method, the structure of the junction and the protein-binding sites are examined and compared. The Raman technique, which examines molecular vibrations, is used to probe the binding site of the ions. By elucidating the nature of these protein-junction complexes and whether they facilitate strand exchange, these studies address the overall mechanism of how DNA recombination occurs in the cell and the overall function of these proteins. This work studies these processes at a basic level and provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of DNA repair and recombination and specifically, the role of these proteins in maintaining a stable genome.

Broader impacts that stem from the project are multifold. Teaching and training of undergraduate and graduate students is one of the main impacts of this work. The PI's academic institution is committed to fostering an environment that promotes the integration of research and education at all levels, including the classroom. Several of the courses taught by the PI draw directly from research in her laboratory. The PI actively works to increase the participation of underrepresented groups in science through her activities as chair of the Minority Affairs Committee of the Biophysical Society. These activities include but are not limited to participation in diversity workshops, guest lecturer in a summer mini-course in Biophysics geared towards underrepresented students and acting as a poster judge at conferences for minority students. In addition, the PI is committed to the advancement of women in science and participates in leadership and mentoring activities at the local and national level. The PI also participates in outreach activities such as 'Minds in Motion' at the K-12 level. The majority of these outreach activities are particularly geared towards groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project in general were to study the structure and conformation of DNA Holliday Junctions alone and in association with proteins.  The junction structures serve as models for important intermediates in the processes of DNA recombination and repair.  In the case of meiotic recombination these structures are key for the exchange of genetic information between homologous chromosomes.  The project specifically focused on determining the changes in junction conformation occurring upon protein binding and the role of ions in modulating junction structure. We also studied model systems to assist us in understanding these protein-junction interactions.  We examined DNA junctions in complex with different proteins to better understand the interactions that promote function and recognition.  Through our studies we have developed a more complete understanding of how these proteins bind and recognize junction substrates and of how the structure of the junction influences the recognition.

 

In the course of performing this work, we have developed innovative new spectroscopic or fluorescence techniques to probe these macromolecular relationships at the nanoscale and determine how they interact. Much of this work relied on the use of the nucleoside analogue, 6-methylisoxanthopterin (6-MI), a guanosine analogue previously used in a number of studies investigating DNA-protein interactions.  A breakthrough in our use of 6-MI came when we identified two pentamer DNA sequences (ATFAA and AAFTA) incorporating 6-MI that significantly enhanced fluorescence quantum yield and could be used to visualize protein-DNA interactions at very low concentrations of DNA. This increased sensitivity has advanced our work considerably by allowing us to make measurements at significantly lower concentrations.  When a protein binds DNA, it often bends the DNA molecule to enable its function, and the 6-MI probe is particularly good for determining the degrees of distortion when this occurs, which also aids us in studying the molecular mechanisms behind binding and recognition.  The enhanced sensitivity has also facilitated our use of the probe to monitor the stability of local regions of DNA.  Other technological advances as a consequence of our work include our development of a mapping technique using Förster Resonance Energy Transfer or FRET.  This mapping technique has enabled us to develop structural models of protein-junction interactions, protein-DNA interactions and protein-protein interactions. 

 

Finally, throughout the course of this work the PI was involved in several teaching and training activities.  Several graduate students (Ph.D. and M.A.) received training and worked on this project.  Their efforts culminated in the publication of journal articles (>15), completed theses and the conferring of degrees.  As the PI is at a small liberal arts institution, several undergraduate students were also actively engaged in this project.  They also contributed to published articles and produced honors theses.  In addition to her standard teaching load, the PI led outreach activities related to the research.  She, along with her students, taught middle school students about DNA through an activity-based exercise designed to identify ‘crime-scene DNA.’  In these workshops, students also engaged in DNA model building and isolated their own DNA from saliva cells.  The PI also developed a similar exercise for a Girls in Science camp, which was very successful.  Throughout the award period, the PI promoted diversity in the scientific workforce through the Minority Affairs Committee of her professional society.  In addition, at her home institution, she developed and directed programs supporting underrepresented groups in the sciences including ethnic minorities, low income students, first generation to college and women students interested in the Physical Sciences and Math.
